posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked:
I know this subject has been brought up before, but I have never seen a reasonable solution to the problem. Our team uses NEO motors almost exclusively.  This means that for simulation we need to deal with the SparkMax. We have tried using the Rev simulation interface, but it has a number of known issues. I believe the current best solution would be some form of ‘Mock’ for the SparkMax that would operate in simulation mode.  Even a very ‘dumb’ motor controller Mock would be nice at this point. I know that some teams have done this in the past (including YAGSL), but I wanted to ask if someone has a more generic solution to this issue.

Thank You

posts.name: asa
posts.cooked: The best solution that my team has found is abstracting all our hardware behind IO interfaces, similar to how teams organize their code when using AdvantageKit. For example, if you want to be able to use a shooter, your code would look something like:

posts.name: Max Morehead
Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked: This is the route we are going as well. It’s a bit of a pain but since it forces us to think of public interfaces and proper encapsulation I’m only a little grumbly.

posts.name: Reza
posts.cooked:
We’ve created a NEO wrapper that makes it more convenient to use NEOs (for us) and enables sim support “out of the box”. Now, when we add new NEOs to our code theyre automatically simmed. It also has support for external absolute encoders as PID feedback devices. You can access our NEO wrapper here and if you rummage around its parent directory, you’ll find our ThroughboreEncoder wrapper as well which is just an external absolute encoder wrapper for NEOs/SparkMaxes.

It’s not optimized very much on that repository, I’ve made it better a bit in our current robot code but haven’t back propogated that to that repo. It’s also pretty much just a collection of workarounds to REVs lack of real sim support so ymmv, for us it works really well and enabled us to get full robot sim running extremely fast once the season started.

refactor the arm subsystem to use an interface

One student went one step further and created a fully controllable (basically mock) ArmIO to use for unit tests for the arm subsystem logic. Mostly for testing that the logic correctly returns “broken states” and wanting to mess around with github actions.

We got to this point a few weeks into build after settling on our initial implementations. Interface composition wasn’t the easiest thing to explain to new programmers (I ended up using USB sticks and game cartridges as examples). After messing with the sim a lot more this year I think we will be leaning this direction heavily going forward.

suggested_topics.excerpt: Not anymore! Its disabled by default now and must be explicitly enabled. I wrote about this in the changelog. To re-enable this feature use SwerveDrive.setModuleEncoderAutoSynchronize

suggested_topics.title: Limelight 3 restarting periodically
suggested_topics.excerpt: plugging the Limelight 3 to the 12V 2A slot on the VRM worked! The limelight now works flawlessly. Thank you everyone for your help!
